page.title: 04Interviewing the Curate
page.content: This is an interview with Michael Alexander Tobias Rubus Aisbit, the Curate of Saint Mary's Church in Norton. The oldest part of the church is 965 years old. It was built in 1020 AD. The oldest part of the church is the tower. The church is the only example of a Saxon Cruciform Church in Northumbria. In the early 19th century the church had balconies but they had to be knocked off or they would have fallen off. The old vicarage (now part of Red House School) was very large. The Vicar owned lots of land which people used to farm and pay rent. This meant the Vicar was very rich. This land was called Glebeland and is now covered in houses. In the church graveyard there are so many graves that you can not be buried there.
